I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) plus the People’s Republic of 
China (PRC), Japan, and the Republic of Korea (ASEAN+3) launched the Asian Bond Markets 
Initiative (ABMI) in December 2002 to (i) foster the development of local currency bond markets 
as  an  alternative  source  of  funding  to  short-term  foreign  currency  loans,  and  (ii)  promote 
regional  financial  cooperation  and  integration  for  a  more  resilient  financial  system.  More 
developed local currency bond markets would (i) help the ASEAN+3 region mobilize savings to 
meet its long-term investment needs, particularly for infrastructure development; and (ii) reduce 
its vulnerability to the sudden reversal of capital inflows, thereby strengthening the region’s 
financial stability. Since the launching of the ABMI, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) has 
provided technical support for this initiative as secretariat. The design and monitoring framework 
is in Appendix 1.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Significant progress has been made by the region in developing local currency bond 
markets since 2002. The amount of outstanding local currency bonds in ASEAN plus the PRC 
and  the  Republic  of  Korea  grew  from  $1.1  trillion  in  2002  to  $10.4  trillion  by  the  end  of 
September 2016. As a percentage of gross domestic product, local currency bonds outstanding 
rose  to  69.9%  in  September  2016  from  42.6%  in  end-2003  across  the  region  in  newly 
developed markets such as Viet Nam and in more advanced markets like the Republic of Korea. 
Yield curves have not only become more reliable, but they have also been gradually lengthened 
across the region. Restrictions have been removed to allow a greater range of entities to issue 
local currency bonds to meet funding needs. There is also a greater variety in the types of 
bonds  being  issued—including  inflation-linked  bonds,  asset-backed  securities,  and  Islamic 
bonds—in debt markets in the region. 
 
3.  Local currency bond markets have now become the key source of funding (i) for the 
authorities to fund public sector programs in Indonesia, the Republic of Korea, Malaysia, the 
Philippines, and Thailand; and (ii) for highly rated corporates to meet their financing needs. The 
Credit Guarantee and Investment Facility, a credit enhancement facility for companies seeking 
to issue local currency-denominated bonds launched by ASEAN+3 under the ABMI in 2010, has 
issued 16 credit guarantees (amounting to $1,024 million) for bonds issued by seven companies 
in six ASEAN member countries, and its board approved two additional guarantees amounting 
to $170 million in 2016. As its guarantee capacity will likely reach its limit by 2017, member 
countries are in the process of deciding on the next steps, including capital increase. 
 
4.  Information  on  individual  bond  markets  across  ASEAN+3  is  now  available  on  the 
AsianBondsOnline website in the form of the ASEAN+3 Bond Market Guide. Regulations across 
ASEAN+3 have markedly improved and, where practical, would be harmonized to facilitate 
cross-border  bond  issuance  and  investment.  Under  the  ASEAN+3  Multi-Currency  Bond 
Issuance Framework,2 the first cross-border pilot bond was issued in 2015 in Thailand by 
Mizuho Bank for B3 billion. The market infrastructure required to support bond markets, ranging 
from the credit rating to the settlement and clearance, has been put in place and will benefit 
from additional work to be undertaken under the Cross-Border Settlement Infrastructure Forum.3 
                                                
1  The technical assistance first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 25 August 2016. 
2  The framework was established to facilitate cross-border bond issuance by making it possible for qualified issuers 
from ASEAN+3 to issue bonds in any participating member country with standardized documentation and well-
defined implementation procedures. 
3  The forum was established to improve cross-border settlement of bonds.

2  
 
5.  To further advance the objectives of the ABMI, the ASEAN+3 finance ministers and 
central bank governors recently approved a medium-term road map outlining activities to be 
supported from 2016 to 2018. In particular, ASEAN+3 will continue to foster the development of 
local currency bond markets to promote financial stability and meet the long-term investment 
needs of the region by expanding the use of local currency bonds to address three key areas of 
financing gaps in the region: (i) small and medium-sized enterprises, (ii) housing, and (iii) 
infrastructure. Activities under the medium-term road map will also seek to advance regional 
market integration. 
 
6.  Building on achievements that promote the use of local currency bonds for infrastructure 
finance,  ASEAN+3  policy  makers  are  exploring  options  to  promote  green  local  currency-
denominated bonds to meet the region’s infrastructure development needs. The policy makers 
have included the promotion of these bonds as an activity to support in the medium term under 
the ABMI. 
 
7.  Financing infrastructure projects with green local currency-denominated bonds is highly 
desirable for the following reasons. First, financing infrastructure projects with long-term local 
currency bonds instead of short-term bank loans denominated in foreign currency would make 
the projects less vulnerable to currency and refinancing risks, especially as they generate 
revenue in the local currency. Without hedging, which comes with a cost and may not be 
available for longer-dated tenors in all currencies, adverse exchange rate movements can 
increase debt service requirements relative to local currency revenue, potentially threatening the 
viability of a project. Second, ASEAN+3 has a significantly large demand for infrastructure but is 
exposed to a range of climate conditions and extreme events. Because of this, green bonds—
the fixed-income instruments where the proceeds raised are used to finance clearly defined 
projects that have environmental benefits, including renewable energy, water conservation, 
energy efficiency, green buildings, clean transport, and sustainable land use—supported within 
the framework of ASEAN+3 would not only help meet the long-term financing of the region, but 
could become an effective investment tool to finance its transition to a low-carbon region. 
 
8.  Green bond markets have recently been developed and, as they have grown, it has 
become  essential  for  the  markets  to  establish  an  industry-wide  framework  to  define  what 
constitutes a green bond. As a result, the Green Bond Principles (GBPs) were prepared by a 
group of leading financial institutions to provide voluntary guidelines for issuers and underwriters 
as benchmarks for green bonds. The GBPs have four components: (i) use of proceeds, (ii) 
process for project evaluation and selection, (iii) management of proceeds, and (iv) reporting. In 
addition, the GBPs recommend that issuers have independent third parties conduct external 
assurance to confirm that the issuance is aligned with the four components of the GBPs. As 
green bond markets are rapidly developing across sectors and geographies, the GBPs have to 
be revised and updated, as required, to remain relevant. 
 
9.  While the GBPs identify the type of projects that would qualify as green bonds, they do 
not define the criteria for the environmental impact and additionality of the projects, and this has 
sometimes raised concerns about greenwashing by issuers. To meet requirements for investors, 
a number of organizations, including the Climate Bonds Initiative, are developing standards to 
define what is considered “green.” These standards, however, are based on the GBPs, and 
bonds issued using these standards are referred to as climate bonds that require certification. 
Nevertheless, as there are additional costs to issue green bonds (e.g., establishing segregated 
treasury accounts, reporting, seeking a second-party opinion, and paying a certification fee in 
case of climate bonds), benefits for green issuers, including a more diversified investor base

3 
and sustainability credentials, would have to be greater than the costs to encourage issuers to 
tap green debt markets. 
 
 
III.  THE RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The  impact  will  be  strengthened  financial  stability  and  support  to  sustainable 
development in the region. The outcome will be increased green local currency-denominated 
bonds for infrastructure finance. 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The technical assistance (TA) will include the following activities: 
 
(i)  Study and provide an assessment on green bond markets in ASEAN+3, including 
existing  and  potential  investors  and  market  size,  and  the  underlying  factors 
determining their demand; and recommend measures to increase regional and 
domestic investors’ awareness of green bond benefits to raise the demand for 
green bonds. 
 
(ii)  Identify the existing issuers and potential issuers of green bonds in ASEAN+3, 
determine  the  additional  costs  of  issuing  green  bonds  compared  with 
conventional  local  currency-denominated  bonds,  and  assess  the  potential 
benefits green bond issuers could gain from tapping green debt markets. 
 
(iii)  Review how green bonds are issued in ASEAN+3 member countries and assess 
whether the GBPs have been used to guide green bond issuance, including (a) 
to what extent the proceeds of the bonds have been used for green projects, and 
(b) whether the designated green project categories provide clear environmental 
benefits that could be assessed and quantified by the issuer. Based on the 
findings, recommend measures to (i) promote issuance of green bonds based on 
the  GBPs  at the  national  and  regional  levels,  and  (ii)  scale  up green  bond 
markets for infrastructure development in ASEAN+3. 
 
(iv)  Present and disseminate the findings and recommendations in para. 11 (i)-(iii)  to 
policy  makers  and  market  regulators  in  ASEAN+3  member  countries  for 
consideration. 
 
(v)  In  consultation  with  market  participants,  prepare  a  feasibility  study  on 
establishing  an  ASEAN+3  green  bonds  collective  investment  schemes  (CIS) 
such as exchange traded fund consisting of green local currency-denominated 
bonds issued by sovereign and quasi-sovereign entities in ASEAN+3 (example is 
the Asian Bond Fund 2 of the Executives’ Meeting of East Asia-Pacific Central 
Banks4) to promote and facilitate investment in green bonds issued within the

region. Provide criteria on the type of bonds the CIS could invest in for the 
selected bonds to meet the GBPs. 
 
(vi)  In  close  collaboration  with  Sustainable  Development  and  Climate  Change 
Department  (SDCC)  staff  and  based  on  discussion  with  green  bond  index 
providers, prepare a feasibility study on establishing an ASEAN+3 green bonds 
index  to  track  the  regional  green  bond  market,  including  the  potential 
methodology and types of bonds to be included in the index for the selected 
bonds to meet the GBPs. The proposed ASEAN+3 green bonds index could be 
effectively used as a performance measure for the ASEAN+3 green bonds CIS 
and other green and broad-based investors. 
 
12.  Output 1: ASEAN+3 regional studies developed and disseminated. The TA team will 
conduct  a  study  on  green  bond  markets  in  ASEAN+3,  including  the  underlying  factors 
determining the demand and supply of green bonds, and whether the GBPs have been used as 
guidelines for green bond issuance. The study will also recommend measures to promote the 
use of green bonds for infrastructure development in the region. Additionally, the TA team will 
conduct two feasibility studies on the establishment of a green bond index in ASEAN+3 and 
ASEAN+3 green bonds CIS. The findings of the studies will be discussed with and provided to 
policy makers in the region for their consideration in support of their efforts to promote green 
bonds in their respective countries.   
 
13.  Output 2: Capacity of ASEAN+3 government staff enhanced. Training of at least 5 
person-days  will  be  conducted for  three groups  of policy  makers from  ASEAN+3 member 
countries  that  are  at  the  same  stage  of  market  development  to  help  them  address  the 
challenges identified with policy recommendations by the studies as highlighted in output 1. 
 
14.  Risks. Project risks include the following: (i) there is unsustained commitment to green 
financing  policies  by  member  countries,  and  (ii)  lack  of  data  compromises  the  quality  of 
recommendations made by the studies as highlighted in output 1. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The TA is estimated to cost $500,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by the 
People’s  Republic  of  China  Regional  Cooperation  and  Poverty  Reduction  Fund  and 
administered by ADB. The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  ADB will be the executing agency for the TA. The Financial Cooperation and Integration 
Team of the Office of the Director General under the SDCC will implement the TA in close 
coordination with ADB’s Southeast Asia Department, East Asia Department, Private Sector 
Operations Department, and Economic Research and Regional Cooperation Department. The 
project will be implemented over 24 months from January 2017 to December 2018. 
 
17.  The TA implementation will be monitored and assessed by representatives from the 
PRC  and Thailand,  which  are  the  co-chairs  of  the  ABMI Task  Force  1  on  Promoting  the 
Issuance (Supply) of Local Currency-Denominated Bonds. Once the studies are completed, 
                                                                                                                                                       
Bank of Korea, Bank Negara Malaysia, Reserve Bank of New Zealand, Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas, Monetary 
Authority of Singapore, and Bank of Thailand.

5 
they will be circulated to other member countries for review and endorsement. The seminars will 
then be held to discuss and disseminate the TA findings to policy makers and regulators in the 
region for their  consideration. The  co-chairs  of the  ABMI  Task  Force  1  on  Promoting the 
Issuance (Supply)  of  Local  Currency-Denominated  Bonds  will  also  report the findings  and 
recommendations under the studies as highlighted in output 1 to the ASEAN+3 Deputy Finance 
Ministers and Central Bank Governors for their endorsement. 
 
18.  The  TA  will  require  9  person-months  of  individual  international  consulting  services 
comprising (i) 4 person-months for the financial market specialist, (ii) 3 person-months for the 
institutional investor, and (iii) 2 person-months for the capital market specialist. Additionally, the 
TA will require 16 person-months of individual national consulting services for the research 
analyst, who will provide support on data and information on infrastructure bonds, help monitor 
the  progress  of  the  TA,  and  organize  meetings  and  workshops  to  support  and  assist 
international consultants and the SDCC. 
 
19.  Consultants will be selected and engaged in accordance with ADB's Guidelines on the 
Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time). The outline terms of reference for 
consultants is in Appendix 3. Disbursement under the TA project will be made in accordance 
with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to 
time). SDCC staff will regularly monitor and administer the individual contracts, and manage the 
combined outputs. If ADB staff act as resource persons, the TA will cover only their travel 
costs.5 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to be financed on a 
grant basis by the People's Republic of China Regional Cooperation and Poverty Reduction 
Fund for Promoting Green Local Currency-Denominated Bonds for Infrastructure Development 
in ASEAN+3, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
                                                
5  A  memo  from  ADB’s  Budget,  Personnel,  and  Management  Systems  Department  and  Strategy  and  Policy 
Department (26 June 2013) provides guidance on charging costs to TA and internal administrative expense

to charge corresponding salaries and benefits to the TA. If the TA paper clearly specifies in its cost estimates that it 
will provide support such as travel and administrative expenses, then such costs should be charged to the TA.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Consultants

advanced degree in economics or finance, and experience and knowledge of related policy 
work in the Association of Southeast Asian Nations plus the People’s Republic of China, Japan, 
and the Republic of Korea (ASEAN+3) region. The specialist, who should also have strong 
writing skills and be able work effectively with policy makers in the region, will undertake the 
following tasks: 
(i)  in close collaboration with the Financial Cooperation and Integration Team of the 
Office of the Director General under the Sustainable Development and Climate 
Change Department (SDCC), (a) undertake a study and provide an assessment 
of green bond markets in ASEAN+3 member countries, including existing and

measures to increase regional and domestic investors’ awareness of green bond 
benefits to raise the demand for green bonds; 
 
(ii)  identify the existing issuers and potential issuers of green bonds in ASEAN+3; 
and  determine  the  additional  costs  of  issuing  green  bonds  compared  with 
conventional  local  currency-denominated  bonds  and  assess  the  potential

(iii)  based on the findings in para. 11 (i)–(iii) of the main text, work together with the

markets for infrastructure development in ASEAN+3; 
 
(iv)  attend an Asian Bond Markets Initiative (ABMI) Task Force meeting to present 
and  disseminate  the  findings  and  recommendations  of  the  study  jointly  with

countries for consideration; and 
 
(v)  disseminate, through workshops, the findings of the study and recommendations

2.  The specialist is expected to 
(i)  have extensive knowledge of local currency bonds (knowledge of green bonds 
for infrastructure finance is highly preferable) in ASEAN+3 member countries, 
 
(ii)  be knowledgeable of various green bonds issued in developed bond markets

(iii)  work effectively with a range of officials in the 13 ASEAN+3 member countries, 
and 
 
(iv)  have excellent verbal and written communication skills in English. 
 
3.  Institutional investor (3 person-months). The institutional investor must have at least 
an advanced degree in economics or finance, and relevant experience in the financial market.

financial  market  specialist  to  recommend  measures  to  scale  up  green  bond 
markets for infrastructure development in ASEAN+3 member countries; 
 
(iii)  attend an ABMI Task Force meeting to present and disseminate the findings and 
recommendations  of the  study jointly  with  SDCC  staff to  policy  makers  and 
market regulators in ASEAN+3 member countries; and 
 
(iv)  disseminate, through workshops, the findings and recommendations of the study 
as highlighted in output 1 to ASEAN+3 policy makers and regulators. 
 
4.  The institutional investor is expected to have 
 
(i)  significant knowledge in investments in fixed-income instruments; 
 
(ii)  experience  working  with  governments,  preferably  with  officials  from  the  13 
ASEAN+3 member countries; and 
 
(iii)  excellent verbal and written communication skills in English. 
 
5.  Capital market specialist (2 person-months). The capital market specialist must have 
at least an advanced degree in economics or finance, and relevant experience working in the 
financial market. The specialist, who should also have good writing skills and be able to work 
effectively with policy makers in the region, will undertake the following tasks: 
 
(i)  In  close  collaboration  with  SDCC  staff  and  in  consultation  with  market 
participants,  prepare  a  feasibility  study  for  establishing  an  ASEAN+3  green 
bonds  collective  investment  schemes  (CIS)  including  exchange  traded  fund 
(ETF)  consisting  of  green  local  currency-denominated  bonds  issued  by 
sovereign and quasi-sovereign entities in ASEAN+3 (similar to the Asian Bond 
Fund 2 of Executives’ Meeting of East Asia-Pacific Central Banks) to promote 
and facilitate investment in green bonds issued within the region. Provide criteria 
on the type of bonds the CIS (including ETF) could invest in to help align the 
selected bonds with the GBPs. 
 
(ii)  In close collaboration with SDCC and based on discussion with green bond index 
providers, prepare a feasibility study for establishing an ASEAN+3 green bonds 
index  to  track  the  regional  green  bond  market,  including  the  potential 
methodology and types of bonds to be included in the index to help align the 
selected bonds with the GBPs. The proposed ASEAN+3 green bonds index

Appendix 3  11 
could be effectively used as a performance measure for both green investors and 
broad-based investors, including for the ASEAN+3 green bonds CIS. 
 
(iii)  Attend an ABMI Task Force meeting to present the feasibility studies on an 
ASEAN+3  green  bond  CIS  and  ASEAN+3  green  bond  index  to  ASEAN+3 
member countries. 
 
(iv)  Together with SDCC staff, disseminate through workshops the feasibility studies 
to ASEAN+3 member countries. 
6.  The specialist is expected to have 
  
(i)  extensive  knowledge  of  local  currency  bonds,  especially  green  bonds  for 
infrastructure finance, in ASEAN+3 member countries; 
 
(ii)  strong knowledge of CIS (including ETF) and bond indexes; 
 
(iii)  experience  working  with  governments,  preferably  with  officials  from  the  13 
ASEAN+3 member countries; and 
 
(iv)  excellent verbal and written communication skills in English. 
 
B.  National Consultant 
7.  Research analyst (16 person-months). The research analyst will be a citizen of the 
Philippines, with a duty station at the Asian Development Bank (ADB) headquarters in Manila. 
The tasks and responsibilities of the research analyst include the following: 
 
(i)  As  directed  by  SDCC  staff  and  international  consultants,  obtain  data  and 
documents related to the project by researching publicly available sources and 
coordinating,  through  consultation  with  ABMI  representatives  and  ADB  staff, 
official requests with the authorities in ASEAN+3 member countries. 
 
(ii)  Conduct analysis and prepare briefing notes on selected topics as directed by 
SDCC staff and international consultants. 
 
(iii)  Work with SDCC staff and international consultants to organize meetings or 
workshops as requested by ASEAN+3 member countries and help disseminate 
the findings under the technical assistance (TA). International travel may be 
required  as the  research  analyst  would  organize  meetings  or  workshops for 
ASEAN+3 member countries to discuss the findings of the TA. 
 
(iv)  Under  the  direction  of  SDCC  staff  and  international  consultants,  and  in 
consultation  with  ABMI  representatives,  contact  country  officials  and  market 
participants to arrange meetings for field work in selected countries in ASEAN+3. 
 
(v)  Monitor the schedule of activities and progress of the TA implementation. 
 
(vi)  Assist  SDCC  staff  and  monitor  and  check  that  the  TA  activities  are  being 
administered  and  implemented  in  accordance  with  pertinent  ADB  rules  and 
guidelines.

12  Appendix 3 
 
8.  The research analyst should preferably have a degree in finance, economics, business, 
or an equivalent field, and should have 
 
(i)  the relevant professional experience required to undertake the tasks in para. 7 
(i)–(vi); 
 
(ii)  more  than  5  years  of experience  in  research  analysis,  preferably  in finance 
and/or economics; 
 
(iii)  a strong background in project coordination; and 
 
(iv)  excellent verbal and written communication skills in English.
